name: Aunt Rocky's Fluffy LCHF Pancakes (Low Carb, Grain Free, Gluten Free, Low Glycemic)
description: Have you been missing a low-carb pancake that has true pancake texture and mouth feel? Here it is! These are so moist and buttery all on their own,  you may not need to top with butter. Just drizzle your favorite sugar-free pancake syrup, jam, or berries over the top and serve. A meal of 2 pancakes is only 237 calories, 2 net carbs, and very filling.  Suitable for: gluten-free, Atkins®, lchf, low-carb, diabetic, low-glycemic. Serve with your favorite pancake syrup or toppings. These are very buttery, so you may not need to top them with more butter. Extra pancakes can be stored in refrigerator or frozen.
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon oat fiber (such as LifeSource Foods®)
½ teaspoon gluten-free baking powder (such as Rumford®)

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk coconut flour, erythritol, oat fiber, baking powder, xanthan gum, and salt together in a bowl, breaking up any lumps in the coconut flour.
Preheat a griddle or pan over medium-low heat and lightly oil the surface.
Mix eggs, butter, water, cream, vinegar, and vanilla extract into the bowl with the coconut flour mixture. Stir well to combine; batter will be thicker than regular pancake batter.

Scoop 1/4 cup batter at a time onto the preheated griddle, leaving space between each pancake and smoothing the tops slightly. Cook until bubbles form, edges begin to dry, and the bottom is browned, 2 to 5 minutes. Flip pancakes carefully using a thin spatula; continue cooking until firm and browned on the second side, about 1 minute more.

aggregateRating.itemReviewed: Aunt Rocky's Fluffy LCHF Pancakes (Low Carb, Grain Free, Gluten Free, Low Glycemic)

review.reviewBody: Only a couple changes: had no oat fiber (whatever that is) so I used flax meal)  and used coconut cream instead of heavy cream (dairy intolerant). They turned out great, just like Auntrocky said. I will definitely make this again.  And another thing, using a 1/4 cup measure, I only got 8 pancakes.

I was very skeptical, how can 1/2 cup coconut flour make enough pancakes...but it did! I did have to add more water otherwise the pancakes wouldn't flatten.  They were really good, I added pecans to mine. The premade mixes are so expensive and I think these tasted a little better. Thanks for a great recipe!
Finally not a grainy pancake texture, like almond flour. The coconut flour goes so well in pancakes. I have tried so many keto pancake recipes and this is by far the Fluffiest and best tasting one!
